 Hello there! "Machuritto" Enquiries can be directed to: \@masugid_enterprise masugidenterprise2b@gmail.com Masugid Enterprise Wani Enterprise “Sa-WAFF Panalo” \@wanienterprise 0951-003-5060 
 
 
 
 Playmaker Enterprise Playmaker Enterprise “Langka-Tulad, Langka-Pantay at 
Langkasing-Sarap na Jack of Pie” Challenge yourself now! C-Verde collaborates with Masugid, Wani, and Playmaker to promote sustainability through user engagement. Users can earn discounts or vouchers by participating in challenges and when users reach specific carbon emission reduction goals. The potential larger discounts are redeemable green products from the enterprises.
<![CDATA[Privacy & Terms 1. Acceptance of Terms Privacy & Terms Ensuring that the information you provide is accurate and up-to-date. Regularly updating the app to benefit from new features and improvements. 4. User Responsibilities You are responsible for: C-Verde collects and processes personal information, such as your daily activities, energy usage, and travel habits, to calculate your carbon footprint. 3. Data Collection and Privacy Avoid any unauthorized access, tampering, or reverse engineering of the application. • Use the app for lawful purposes and in compliance with all applicable laws. • Provide accurate data regarding your activities to ensure accurate carbon footprint tracking. C-Verde is a carbon footprint tracker that allows users to monitor and reduce their environmental impact. By using the application, you agree to: 2. Use of the Application By downloading, installing, or using the C-Verde application, you agree to be bound by these Terms and Conditions. If you do not agree to these terms, please do not use the application. Last Name POINTS: 85 Collect points to redeem special awards Your Total Carbon Footprint: 0.00 g CO₂ Walking Bike Logout About
C-Verde C-Verde c.verde0101@gmail.com 
 
 
 " C-Verde is an innovative mobile application designed to help individuals monitor and reduce their carbon footprint in an accessible way. By tracking daily activities like transportation, electricity usage, food consumption, and waste generation, " 
 To reduce food waste, start by planning your meals and creating a grocery list to avoid impulse buys. Store food properly in airtight containers, and label leftovers with dates. Practice portion control when serving meals and get creative with leftovers. Your Challenges Take daily actions to reduce your carbon footprint, earn rewards for each completed challenge, and build sustainable habits. Let’s create a greener future together! In Progress
Hello blank fragment
*
COMPLETED Challenge Goal: Reduce your carbon footprint by choosing plant-based meals instead of meat. Go Meatless for One Day! Start Challenge Carry a Reusable Water Bottle Challenge Goal: Use a reusable water bottle instead of buying plastic ones.. Plan a Zero-Waste Meal Challenge Goal: Use ingredients you already have at home to prepare a mea DONE Later Eating plant-based meals instead of meat significantly reduces greenhouse gas emissions, conserves water, and lowers energy use associated with food production. By opting for plant-based alternatives, you can make a tangible positive impact on the environment while exploring diverse, nutritious, and delicious food options. -10 kg CO2 (-0.21% of your footprint) COMPLETED Challenges "
You've successfully completed Day One of the challenge and earned points. Thank you for making the effort to stay green! " -10 kg CO2 Many electronics continue to consume energy even when turned off, a phenomenon known as "phantom" or "standby" power. By unplugging devices such as chargers, appliances, and entertainment systems when they’re not in use, you can significantly cut down on unnecessary energy consumption, lower your carbon footprint, and save on electricity bills. This simple habit can make a big difference in reducing overall energy waste.

This challenge helps build sustainable habits while contributing to energy conservation and reducing unnecessary environmental impact. Single-use plastic water bottles contribute significantly to pollution and landfill waste, taking hundreds of years to decompose. By switching to a reusable water bottle, you reduce plastic waste, minimize your carbon footprint, and help conserve resources. It’s an easy and effective way to stay hydrated while supporting a more sustainable lifestyle.

This challenge not only reduces plastic waste but also encourages healthier hydration habits. Instead of buying takeout or extra groceries, this challenge encourages you to get creative with what’s already in your pantry, fridge, or freezer. Not only does this reduce food waste and save money, but it also promotes resourcefulness and helps you discover new ways to combine ingredients. By using what you have on hand, you can create delicious, budget-friendly meals while minimizing your environmental footprint.

This challenge helps you minimize food waste, save money, and make the most of what’s already in your kitchen. Over time, old emails and files accumulate, taking up unnecessary space on your devices and cloud storage. By organizing and deleting outdated or unused files, you can improve device performance, make it easier to find important information, and reduce your digital footprint. This challenge encourages digital decluttering, helping you stay organized while contributing to more efficient use of storage resources.

This challenge helps you maintain a cleaner, more organized digital environment while improving device efficiency and security. 
 Your actions are harming the environment. But it’s never too late to make a positive change! Start by taking on these daily challenges. OK MASUGID’s Product "On November 14, 2024, the enterprise launched a new product, a churro with chocolate filling." " is a student-led business from Quezon City University (QCU) offering churros with a unique twist—served with creamy matcha. This venture combines the popular snack of churros with a rich, smooth matcha flavor, appealing to those who enjoy classic treats with a modern, flavorful upgrade." “Our newest chocolate flavor has arrived. It is rich, sweet, and made to satisfy your chocolate cravings." WANI’s Product WANI’s Promo " run by Quezon City University (QCU) students, offers unique, savory waffles for an affordable 25 pesos each. With flavors like asado and adobo, the business blends Filipino-inspired tastes with the popular waffle format, aiming to provide a satisfying and budget-friendly snack for students and the local community." " students from Quezon City University, pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Entrepreneurship, founded Playmaker Enterprise. With a shared vision of making a positive impact on the culinary landscape, they introduced innovative jackfruit-infused pies.

By leveraging their skills and passion, they created a business that not only generates profits but also supports local agriculture and sustainability. Their commitment to quality, innovation, and customer satisfaction has made Playmaker Enterprise a rising star in the food industry, delighting customers with their unique and delicious treats." Attendance Checked Categories Quiz Videos Leaderboards February 2025 Tuesday Foodprint Facts back Start Test your knowledge on carbon footprints in food and travel! Uncover the hidden emissions behind your everyday choices with Emission Mission. CO₂ Cuisine Are your favorite foods secretly harming the planet? Total Points: Question 1/5 A reusable container for drinking water. A. Water Bottle B. Plastic Bottle C. Glass Cup D. Aluminum Cup E. None of the above Question 2/5 A way to reduce waste of plastic bags. A. Burning them B. Throwing away C. Storing them without using D. Reuse Creatively E. Both C & D SUBMIT A vehicle that uses electricity instead of gasoline. A. Gasoline Car B. Electric Car C. Diesel Truck D. Hybrid Car E. Both B & D Question 3/5 Question 4/5 A type of vehicle that does not release any greenhouse gases. A. Bus C. Bicycle D. Scooter E. Tractors The process of turning food scraps into nutrient-rich soil. A. Recycling B. Dumping C. Planting D. Composting E. All of the above Well Done! Your final score is: 0/5 points "You’ve completed the quiz and earned extra points! Thanks for taking a step toward protecting the environment—every effort counts! " GREEN OR MEAN? 5pts. Start Game Play Can you dodge the junk food and grab the healthy snacks before time runs out? FOOD DROP I'm here! Recommended for you Breakfast Lunch Snack Dinner Egg Toast 10 min. ~500 cal. MOVE Green Did you know? TRACK MY TRIP SPHERE IN A JAR Explore Replicate the Earth’s 
major psheres by 
making a terrarium. MELTING ICE You can see from this activity
how melting ice from
cryosphere leads to rise in sea
level. WEATHER WATCHING Try studying your weather
for a week. Take note of
the weather and daily
temperature at the same
time every morning using
a thermometer, your
phone, or local weather
reports. ARRHENIUS EXPERIMENT This simple experiment will show
how Arrhenius’ observation led
him to make the connection
between carbon dioxide and the
warming of the Earth. RAIN IN A JAR EXPERIMENT "This experiment will show how
an increase in temperature
make a difference in the
amount of rainfall. " CREATING A FLOOD BARRIER In this chapter, you will get to learn
about the impacts of climate
change and think or more methods
of adapting to it. LIVING WITH OUR ENVIRONMENT: SUSTAINABILITY "It is better to maintain the state of
the environment than to wait until
we have significantly depleted
natural resources before trying to
replace them. " Open Camera Learn More 20 min. Pancakes Activity YOU can do Instructions: You will need • The model you made in melting ice experiment, refilled with water.
• Empty water bottle.
• A pack of toothpicks or fallen branches, flower stems or plants. Procedure: 1. Study your current model. What do you think can be done to prevent the waves from reaching the houses?
2. Try making a barrier by sticking toothpicks up in the clay along the waterline.
3. Roll the bottle to make waves. How successful is your barrier? What else do you think you could do to keep water from reaching the houses and buildings? Try it on your model. Compare your methods and results with each of your classmates In this chapter, you will get to learn about the impacts of climate change and think or more methods of adapting to it. This app is informed by insights from Klimaalam written by Raissa Rivera Falgui illustrated by Harry Monzo (2022). Acknowledgement "List down the most common climate hazards where you live. Which is your community most at risk of in the rainy season? In the dry season?

List down the common ways that help you adapt to these top climate hazards. Assess whether any of you answers are forms of maladaptation. Come up with better alternatives for the maladaptations. " “Sustainable development is to make the world a better place for everyone now, without destroying the possibilities for the next generations.” - Arindam Basu "It is better to maintain the state of the environment than to wait until we have significantly depleted natural resources before trying to replace them. " ○ Two thermometers
○ A clear glass jar/bottle big enough to hold one of the thermometers. DO THIS IN SUNNY DAY. 1. Turn both thermometers on and put one inside the jar. Cover it.
2. Lay the jar in direct sunlight on its side, with the other thermometer beside it, but not touching it. Make sure that the sun is shining directly on both thermometers.
3. Check temperature after two minutes. Which one has the higher temperature? How many degrees is the difference? This simple experiment will show how Arrhenius’ observation led him to make the connection between carbon dioxide and the warming of the Earth. • 2 bars of modeling clay
• Small objects like rocks or bottle caps to simulate structures
• A rectangular container measuring approximately 8 x 13 inches
• A tightly sealed drinking bottle shorter than the container’s width
• 6 ice cubes 1. Shape the modeling clay into two flat-topped land masses.
2. Position the clay at opposite ends of the container. Fill the container with water until the clay is submerged halfway.
3. Press small objects into one clay mass to represent houses and buildings, ensuring they are placed in various areas above the waterline.
4. Use the plastic bottle to create waves by bouncing or rolling it toward the clay.
5. Place ice cubes on the clay at the opposite end to represent glaciers. Leave the setup in a warm area and observe any changes over time.
6. Once observations are complete, pour out the water and store the setup for future use if desired. You can see from this activity how melting ice from the cryosphere leads to rise in sea levels. ○ Two identical glass jars or bottles
○ Ceramic Saucers
○ Boiling Water
○ 6 Ice Cubes 1. Fill about 1/2 of one jar with room temperature water and the other with the same amount of boiling water.
2. Place a saucer on the top of each jar.
3. After three minutes, put three ice cubes in each saucer. What happened inside each jar? In the experiment, water quickly evaporates and condenses in the jar with hot water. In the same way, greater heat causes more water from the surface of the Earth to evaporate, condense, then turn into rain. "This experiment will show how an increase in temperature make a difference in the amount of rainfall. " "○ A container for your terrarium (you may repurpose a large clear wide-mouthed glass jar or plastic bottle)
○ A small plants like pansit-pansitan, ferns, wood sorrel, oxalis, or golden pothos
○ Small spade or any tool for digging. " 1. At the bottom of the jar, dampen the soil and idg enough space for you plans, covering their roots with soil. Make sure they do not touch the sides of your terrarium.
2. Close and seal the terrarium again then it by a sunny window.
3. Observe your plant. Are they able to survive without being watered. Replicate the Earth’s major spheres by making a terrarium! "○ A container for your terrarium (you may repurpose a large clear wide-mouthed glass jar or plastic bottle)
○ A small plants like pansit-pansitan, ferns, wood sorrel, oxalis, or golden pothos
○ Small spade or any tool for digging. " 1. At the bottom of the jar, dampen the soil and idg enough space for you plans, covering their roots with soil. Make sure they do not touch the sides of your terrarium.
2. Close and seal the terrarium again then it by a sunny window.
3. Observe your plant. Are they able to survive without being watered. Replicate the Earth’s major spheres by making a terrarium!

 Enter your birthday Your BMI Score: 0.0 Your BMI Result: Calculate BMI Our Entrprise Partners What is your primary mode of transportation? Capture Image Select from Gallery Results will appear here Update my Password now Achievements & Badges Breakfast Challenge: Kumain ng bato Ingredients: ▸ 2 slices of bread (whole wheat or white)
▸ 2 eggs
▸ 1 tablespoon butter or cooking oil
▸ Salt and pepper to taste
▸ ¼ teaspoon paprika (optional)
▸ 1 tablespoon milk (optional, for fluffier eggs)
▸ Grated cheese (optional)
▸ Chopped parsley or chives for garnish (optional) 1. Prepare the bread – If desired, make a hole in the center of each bread slice using a cup or cookie cutter (for egg-in-a-hole style). Otherwise, keep the bread whole.
2. Heat the pan – Add butter or oil to a non-stick pan and set to medium heat.
3. Cook the eggs
▹ For egg-in-a-hole style: Place the bread on the pan, crack an egg into the hole, and cook for about 2 minutes. Flip carefully and cook for another minute.
▹ For scrambled eggs on toast: Beat the eggs with milk, salt, and pepper. Pour into the pan, scramble until cooked, then place on toasted bread.
▹ For fried egg toast: Fry the egg separately and place it on top of toasted bread.
4. Add toppings – Sprinkle cheese, paprika, and herbs for extra flavor.
5. Serve warm – Pair with fresh fruit or a cup of tea/coffee for a complete breakfast. LET'S DO IT! Transform your daily commute with eco-friendly choices using insightful tips and trip-tracking tools. Opt for greener alternatives like biking, walking, or public transit and contribute to a cleaner, healthier world! A single gas-powered car emits 4.6 tons of CO₂ yearly—equivalent to burning over 500 gallons of gasoline! "If you walk instead of driving just one mile, you prevent about 404 grams of CO₂ from entering the atmosphere. " Riding a bike cuts carbon emissions by over 90% compared to driving!. Pedal for a greener planet! 🌱♻️ My Rewards Redeem
Chicken
Dairy
Seafood
Nuts
Eggs
None
Enjoy the perks! Your points 
have been redeemed—go 
treat yourself! 1000 points to redeem 5% discount Woohoo! You've grabbed a deal! CLAIM NOW! Points once redeemed will not be refunded. Do you want to redeem? GREEN OR MEAN? Prove your eco-smarts with every drop! High Carbon Low Carbon Score: 0 Finish 
 Game Over Restart High Score What is one of the best ways to lower your food-related carbon footprint? A. Buying locally grown food B. Eating only packaged foods C. Importing exotic foods from other countries D. Cooking with excessive energy Why is reducing food waste important for the environment? A. It helps lower methane emissions from landfills B. It has no impact on carbon emissions C. It makes food more expensive D. It increases the need for transportation What type of diet generally has a lower carbon footprint? A. A diet high in red meat B. A plant-based diet C. A diet based on processed foods D. A diet that includes imported seafood Why is buying food in bulk a good way to lower carbon emissions? A. It reduces packaging waste B. It increases transportation emissions C. It encourages food waste D. It makes food spoil faster E. Both A & B Quiz 5/5 What is one way to reduce the environmental impact of food packaging? A. Choosing products with excessive plastic wrapping B. Buying in bulk to reduce packaging waste C. Ignoring recycling labels on packaging D. Using more single-use plastic containers E. All of the above OR Select one to continue Your lives: 3 Not Applicable BATTLE ECO 0
Your choices impact the planet! Here’s what you learned:

 ✅ Transportation: Walk, bike, or use public transport to reduce emissions.

 ✅ Food: Eat more plant-based and local foods to lower your carbon footprint.

 ✅ Small Changes Matter! Every eco-friendly choice helps fight climate change.

 Keep making sustainable choices! 🌱♻️
WELL DONE! Green Transition Emission Impossible Pause Restart
C-Verde is an innovative mobile app developed by Quezon City University Bachelor of Science Information Technology students from section SBIT-4H to help users monitor and reduce their carbon footprint by tracking transportation, food consumption, and waste. It provides insights, tailored recommendations, and Eco-friendly challenges to encourage sustainable habits. Completing these challenges earns users rewards from enterprises that support environmental sustainability, promoting continued engagement and greener practices.

C-Verde is not just an app; it’s a movement toward a more sustainable future. 
Whether you want to make a small change or a big lifestyle shift, C-Verde gives Quezon City University users the tools and inspiration to help create a greener planet. \@cVerdeOfficial Oatmeal with Peanut Butter 
 & Banana ~0.6 kg CO₂
 ~0.7 kg CO₂
 "A power-packed, fiber-filled breakfast to fuel your mind and body throughout the day!" Oatmeal is an excellent source of complex carbohydrates, helping you stay full longer while maintaining steady energy levels throughout the morning. Adding bananas brings natural sweetness and potassium, which helps prevent muscle cramps and supports heart health. Peanut butter provides healthy fats and protein, making this meal a great alternative to processed breakfast options.
 • ½ cup oats
• 1 tbsp peanut butter
• 1 banana (sliced)
• 1 cup water or plant-based milk 1. In a small saucepan, bring 1 cup of water (or plant-based milk) to a simmer.
2. Stir in oats, cooking on low heat for 5 minutes while stirring to prevent lumps.
3. Once the oatmeal thickens, turn off the heat and mix in peanut butter for a creamy texture.
4. Slice a banana and top it over the oatmeal.
5. Serve warm and enjoy this nutritious, heart-healthy, and delicious breakfast! • Underweight: 450 kcal (add extra peanut butter)
• Normal: 400 kcal
• Overweight: 320 kcal (reduce peanut butter, increase banana) Boiled Kamote with Peanut Butter ~0.5 kg CO₂
 "A sweet, simple, and nutrient-packed breakfast to start your day right!"

 Sweet potatoes (kamote) are a nutritional powerhouse, filled with fiber, vitamin A, and complex carbohydrates to sustain your energy levels throughout the day. Kamote also has a lower glycemic index than white rice, helping to regulate blood sugar levels. Pairing it with peanut butter adds plant-based protein and healthy fats, making this meal an easy, budget-friendly, and eco-conscious choice. • 1 medium sweet potato (kamote)
• 1 tbsp peanut butter 1. Wash the kamote thoroughly and place it in a pot of water.
2. Bring to a boil and let cook for 15-20 minutes or until the kamote is fork-tender. Let cool slightly, then peel and slice.
3. Spread peanut butter on each slice for a delicious, creamy topping.
4. Enjoy warm or at room temperature as a simple, satisfying breakfast! • Underweight: 350 kcal (add extra peanut butter)
• Normal: 320 kcal
• Overweight: 250 kcal (reduce peanut butter Ginisang Monggo 
with Malunggay & Rice ~1.2 kg CO₂ “A protein-packed, fiber-rich meal that’s good for your health and even better for the planet!"
 Monggo (mung beans) is one of the best plant-based protein sources available in the Philippines! It is fiber-rich, filling, and packed with iron—essential for preventing fatigue and boosting energy. The addition of malunggay leaves increases its vitamin A, calcium, and antioxidants, making this dish a nutrient powerhouse. Unlike meat-based meals, this hearty dish reduces environmental impact while nourishing your body!
 • ½ cup monggo (mung beans)
• 1 cup water
• 1 tbsp coconut oil
• 1 small onion, chopped
• 2 cloves garlic, minced
• ½ cup malunggay leaves
• ½ cup cooked rice 1. Rinse the mung beans and soak them for at least 30 minutes (for faster cooking)
2. In a pot, bring 1 cup of water to a boil and add the mung beans. Cook until they are soft (about 20 minutes)
3. In a separate pan, heat coconut oil and sauté garlic and onions until fragrant.
4. Add the cooked mung beans, stirring to mix all flavors.
5. Toss in the malunggay leaves, letting them cook for 2-3 minutes.
6. Serve hot with rice for a hearty, budget-friendly, and eco-friendly meal! • Underweight: 550 kcal (add extra rice and coconut oil)
• Normal: 500 kcal
• Overweight: 400 kcal (reduce rice, add more malunggay) Ginataang Talong with Rice ~1.0 kg CO₂ "A creamy, smoky, and flavorful dish that brings out the best of Filipino cuisine—without the guilt!"
 Eggplants are low in calories yet high in fiber, making them filling and satisfying. Cooking them in coconut milk adds a rich, creamy texture without using dairy, making this dish both vegan-friendly and flavorful. The smoky taste of eggplant enhances the dish’s umami depth, proving that you don’t need meat for a delicious meal! • 1 large eggplant (talong), sliced
• ½ cup coconut milk
• 2 cloves garlic, minced
• 1 small onion, chopped
• 1 tbsp coconut oil
• ½ cup cooked rice 1. Slice the eggplant and roast or grill it for a smoky flavor
2. In a pan, heat coconut oil and sauté garlic and onions until soft
3. Add the eggplant and pour in coconut milk, letting it simmer for about 5 minutes
4. Stir occasionally until the mixture thickens and the flavors blend well
5. Serve hot over rice, and enjoy a rich, comforting plant-based dish! • Underweight: 500 kcal (extra coconut milk)
• Normal: 450 kcal
• Overweight: 380 kcal (reduce coconut milk, increase eggplant) Ginisang Pechay with Tofu & Rice ~0.9 kg CO₂ "A light yet protein-rich meal that keeps you full and energized without weighing you down!"
 Tofu is a plant-based protein powerhouse, rich in iron, calcium, and essential amino acids. When combined with pechay (Chinese cabbage), this dish becomes low in calories but packed with fiber and vitamins. It’s a light yet satisfying meal that promotes digestion and gut health, while also being super budget-friendly!
 1 ½ block firm tofu, cubed
1 bunch pechay, chopped
2 cloves garlic, minced
• 1 tbsp soy sauce
• ½ tbsp coconut oil
• ½ cup cooked rice a. Heat coconut oil in a pan and lightly fry the cubed tofu until golden brown. Set aside.
b. In the same pan, sauté garlic until fragrant. Add pechay and stir-fry for 2-3 minutes.
c. Add soy sauce, then return the tofu to the pan. Stir well to coat the tofu with flavors.
e. Simmer for another 2 minutes, then serve over rice.
d. Enjoy a light, nutrient-packed, and satisfying plant-based meal! • Underweight: 500 kcal (more tofu)
• Normal: 450 kcal
• Overweight: 380 kcal (less tofu, more pechay) Laing (Dried Taro Leaves in 
Coconut Milk) with Rice ~1.1 kg CO₂ "A creamy, flavorful dish that brings the rich taste of coconut and the goodness of greens to your plate."
 Laing is a classic Bicolano dish made from dried taro leaves cooked in coconut milk, providing a perfect blend of creaminess and spice. Taro leaves are packed with fiber, iron, and vitamins A and C, while coconut milk adds healthy fats that keep you full. Unlike meat-based dishes, laing has a much lower carbon footprint while still offering rich and satisfying flavors.
 1 cup dried taro leaves
½ cup coconut milk
• 1 clove garlic, minced
• 1 small onion, chopped
• ½ cup cooked rice 1. In a pot, heat a small amount of coconut milk and sauté garlic and onions until fragrant.
2. Add the dried taro leaves and let them absorb the coconut milk. Do not stir immediately to prevent itching from the raw leaves.
3. Pour in the rest of the coconut milk and let the mixture simmer for 10-15 minutes until the leaves are tender.
4. Serve hot with rice for a comforting, creamy meal. • Underweight: 550 kcal (extra coconut milk and rice)
• Normal: 500 kcal
• Overweight: 400 kcal (less coconut milk, more taro leaves) Pinakbet with Brown Rice ~1.0 kg CO₂ "A vibrant mix of vegetables that brings out the natural flavors of the land in a single, nutritious dish."
 Pinakbet is a traditional Ilocano dish made with local vegetables like squash, okra, and eggplant, giving you a mix of vitamins, minerals, and fiber. It’s a great way to enjoy a variety of plant-based nutrients while keeping your meal low in carbon emissions. The use of fermented shrimp paste adds natural umami flavor without needing meat. ½ cup squash, cubed
½ cup eggplant, sliced
½ cup okra, chopped
1 tbsp fermented shrimp paste (bagoong)
• 1 clove garlic, minced
• 1 tbsp coconut oil
• ½ cup cooked brown rice 1. Heat coconut oil in a pan and sauté garlic until fragrant.
2. Add the squash first, as it takes the longest to cook, followed by eggplant and okra.
3. Pour in a small amount of water and let the vegetables simmer until tender.
4. Add the fermented shrimp paste and mix well to coat the vegetables.
5. Serve with brown rice for a fiber-rich, healthy meal. • Underweight: 500 kcal (extra coconut oil and brown rice)
• Normal: 450 kcal
• Overweight: 380 kcal (less oil, more vegetables) Tofu and Sitaw (String Beans)
 Stir-Fry with Rice ~0.9 kg CO₂
 "A protein-rich, budget-friendly meal that’s both delicious and sustainable."
 Tofu is an excellent meat alternative packed with protein and essential nutrients, while sitaw (string beans) adds fiber, vitamins, and a light crunch. This dish is easy to cook, affordable, and great for anyone looking for a satisfying but light dinner.
 ½ block firm tofu, cubed
1 cup sitaw, chopped
1 tbsp soy sauce
• 1 clove garlic, minced
• 1 tbsp coconut oil
• ½ cup cooked rice 1. Heat coconut oil in a pan and lightly fry the cubed tofu until golden brown. Set aside.
2. In the same pan, sauté garlic until fragrant.
3. Add the chopped sitaw and stir-fry for about 3 minutes.
4. Add the tofu back into the pan, pour in soy sauce, and mix well.
5. Let it cook for another 2 minutes, then serve over rice. • Underweight: 500 kcal (extra tofu and rice)
• Normal: 450 kcal
• Overweight: 380 kcal (less rice, more vegetables) C-Verde collaborates with Masugid, Wani, and Playmaker to promote sustainability through user engagement. Users can earn discounts or vouchers by participating in challenges and when users reach specific carbon emission reduction goals. The potential larger discounts are redeemable green products from the enterprises. C-Verde is an innovative platform that empower individuals and enterprises to take part in top-tier carbon activities. Cverde Emission Mission What type of food has the lowest carbon footprint? A.
